{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}} {{Dablink|For the football team section, see [[FenerbahÃ§e S.K. (football)]]}} {{Dablink|For other uses of FenerbahÃ§e, see [[FenerbahÃ§e (disambiguation)]].}} {{Infobox football club |clubname = FenerbahÃ§e Spor KulÃ¼bÃ¼ |image = [[Image:FenerbahÃ§e.svg|200px|FenerbahÃ§e]] |fullname = FenerbahÃ§e Spor KulÃ¼bÃ¼ |nickname = ''SarÄ± Kanaryalar'' (The Yellow Canaries)
''SarÄ± Lacivertliler'' (The Yellow-Navy Blues) |founded = 3 May 1907 |chairman = [[Aziz YÄ±ldÄ±rÄ±m]]{{cite news | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2011/jul/10/fenerbahce-aziz-yildirim-turkey-istanbul | title=Fenerbahce president held in custody over match-fixing allegations |work=The Guardian |location=UK | date=10 July 2011 | agency=Press Association | accessdate=12 July 2011}} | website = http://www.fenerbahce.org/ }} '''FenerbahÃ§e Spor KulÃ¼bÃ¼''' ({{lang-en|FenerbahÃ§e Sports Club}}) ({{IPA-tr|feÌËnÃ¦É¾bÃ¤htÍ¡ÊÉ}}) is a professional [[sports club]] based in [[KadÄ±kÃ¶y]], [[Istanbul]], [[Turkey]]. The club derives its name from the [[FenerbahÃ§e (Istanbul_neighbourhood)|FenerbahÃ§e]] neighbourhood of [[Istanbul]]. FenerbahÃ§e is one of the biggest and the best supported clubs in Turkey. They are nicknamed ''SarÄ± Kanaryalar'' {{lang-en|The Yellow Canaries}}). FenerbahÃ§e is a multi-sports club and competes in [[Association football|football]], [[basketball]], [[volleyball]], [[track and field athletics|athletics]], [[Swimming (sport)|swimming]], [[sailing]], [[rowing (sport)|rowing]], [[boxing]] and [[table tennis]] with honours won in each branch. The club is also one of the major contributors of Turkish representatives for the [[Olympic Games]].{{fact|date=September 2011}} The club has 219.456 members as of 12 Sep 2011.{{facts|date=October 2011}} {{FenerbahÃ§e S.K. sections}} ==History== FenerbahÃ§e S.K. was founded in 1907 in [[KadÄ±kÃ¶y]], [[Istanbul]] as a football club by local men [[Ziya SongÃ¼len]] (then Nurizade Ziya [[Bey]]), [[Ayetullah Bey|Ayetullah]] [[Bey]] and Enver Necip Okaner (then Enver Necip [[Bey]]). This group of individuals founded the club secretly in order to keep a low profile and not get into any trouble with the strict [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] rule. At that time the Sultan, [[Abdul Hamid II]], forbade the Turkish youth from setting up a club nor engaging in the game of football. SongÃ¼len was elected the first president of the club, Ayetullah Bey became the first General Secretary, and Okaner was given the post of the General Captain.{{cite web| url=http://www.fenerbahce.org/kurumsaldetay.asp?ContentID=6 | title=TarihÃ§e | work=Fenerbahce.org | accessdate=2007-04-15}} The [[lighthouse]] situated on the FenerbahÃ§e cape was a big influence on the design of the club's first emblem, which sported the yellow and white colors of [[daffodil]]s around the lighthouse. The kits were also designed with yellow and white stripes. The emblem and colors of the club were changed in 1910 when [[Topuz Hikmet]] redesigned the badge and Ziya Bey changed the colors to yellow and navy, still seen today. FenerbahÃ§e's activities were kept in secrecy until a legislation reform in 1908, when, under a new law, all football clubs had to register to exist legally. FenerbahÃ§e joined the Istanbul League in 1909, finishing fifth in their first year. The founding line-up included [[Ziya SongÃ¼len]], [[Ayetullah Bey|Ayetullah]] [[Bey]], Necip Okaner, Galip KulaksÄ±zoÄlu, Hasan Sami Kocamemi, Asaf BeÅpÄ±nar, Enver Yetiker, Åevkati Hulusi [[Bey]], Fuat HÃ¼snÃ¼ Kayacan, Hamit HÃ¼snÃ¼ Kayacan, and Nasuhi Baydar.{{cite web| url=http://www.fenerbahce.org/kurumsaldetay.asp?ContentID=7 | title=TarihÃ§e â 4. Sayfa | work=Fenerbahce.org | accessdate=2007-04-16}} Fenerbahce played against the staff of the [[Royal Navy]] that [[Occupation of Constantinople|occupied Istanbul]] during the [[Turkish War of Independence]].{{cite web| url=http://www.angelfire.com/d20/tfab/1922/ana.html | title=MÃ¼ttefik Kuvvetler ile Yapilan MaÃ§lar | work=TFAB | accessdate=2007-06-14}} The club's [[FenerbahÃ§e Ãlker|basketball section]] was founded in 1913. [[File:Ziya songulen.jpg|left|150px|thumb|Ziya SongÃ¼len.]] The [[Turkish Football Federation]] founded a national league in 1959. FenerbahÃ§e won the [[Turkish National League 1959|first tournament]], beating [[Galatasaray S.K. (football team)|Galatasaray S.K.]] 4â1 on aggregate.{{cite web |url=http://www.angelfire.com/nj/sivritepe/5859/tl.html |title=1959 Milli Lig |work=ErdinÃ§ Sivritepe |accessdate=2007-06-17 }} The next year, FenerbahÃ§e participated in the [[European Cup 1959â60|European Cup]] for the first time. They qualified through a 4â3 win over [[Csepel SC]]. They lost their first round game to [[OGC Nice]] 1â5 in a playoff game after drawing on aggregate.{{cite web| url=http://www.rsssf.com/ec/ec195960.html | title=European Competitions 1959â60 | work=James M. Ross and [[RSSSF]] | accessdate=2007-06-17}} FenerbahÃ§e became the most successful Turkish club of the 1960s. They were also runners-up three times.{{cite web| url=http://www.angelfire.com/nj/sivritepe/artl.html | title=Archives | last=Sivritepe | first=ErdinÃ§ | work=Turkish-soccer.com | accessdate=2007-05-02}}{{cite web| url=http://www.tff.org/default.aspx?pageID=379 | title=TURKCELL SÃPER LIG SAMPIYONLUKLARI | work=TFF.org | accessdate=2007-06-17}} In the [[Balkans Cup 1966â67]] (a competition set up for Eastern European clubs from [[Albania]], Bulgaria, [[Greece]], Romania, [[Turkey]], and [[Yugoslavia]] that existed between the 1960â61 and 1993â94 seasons), FenerbahÃ§e won the cup after three matches against [[Greece|Greek]] club [[AEK Athens FC]], making them the first Turkish club to win a non-domestic competition. This success would remain unparalleled by a Turkish club until [[SarÄ±yer G.K.]] and [[Samsunspor]] won the cup many years later in the 1990s. The 1970s saw Galatasaray win four more league titles. The decade also saw the first non-Istanbul club and a club outside of FenerbahÃ§e, [[Besiktas J.K.]], and [[Galatasaray S.K. (football team)|Galatasaray S.K.]] to win a league title. [[Trabzonspor]] went on to win four titles during the decade. FenerbahÃ§e won three titles in the 1980s, titles Galatasaray S.K. and Besiktas J.K. dominated the Turkish League during the 1990s, combining to win nine out of 10 ti FenerbahÃ§e's only Turkish League success during the 1990s came in the 1995â1996 season under [[Carlos Alberto Parreira]]. FenerbahÃ§e won the league in 2001, denying Galatasaray a fifth consecutive title. They followed up the next season with a runners-up place behind Galatasaray with new coach [[Werner Lorant]]. The [[SÃ¼per Lig 2002â03|next season]], however, did not go so well as FenerbahÃ§e finished in sixth place with [[Ariel Ortega]] in the squad.{{cite web| url=http://www.angelfire.com/nj/sivritepe/0203/1.html | title=2002â2003 1.SÃ¼per Lig | work=ErdinÃ§ Sivritepe | accessdate=2007-06-17}} Despite this, that season is memorable to many FenerbahÃ§e fans due to a 6â0 win against arch-rivals Galatasaray in [[ÅÃ¼krÃ¼ SaracoÄlu Stadium]] on 6 November 2002.{{cite web| url=http://www.fenerbahcecumhuriyeti.org/Film_Afisleri_6-0.asp | title=6 November Victory | work=fenerbahcecumhuriyeti.org | accessdate=2007-09-02}} After firing Werner Lorant, they hired another German coach, [[Christoph Daum]]. Daum had previously coached in Turkey, winning the league with Besiktas J.K. in 1994â95. FenerbahÃ§e brought in players including [[Pierre van Hooijdonk]], [[Mehmet AurÃ©lio]], and [[Fabio Luciano]] as a rebuilding process. These new players lead FenerbahÃ§e to their fifteenth title and third star (one being awarded for every 5 league titles won by a club).{{cite web| url=http://www.angelfire.com/nj/sivritepe/0304/1.html | title=2003â2004 1.SÃ¼per Lig | work=ErdinÃ§ Sivritepe | accessdate=2007-06-17}} The [[SÃ¼per Lig 2004â05|next year]] was followed up by a narrow championship over Trabzonspor, winning the then record of sixteen Turkish First Football League championships.{{cite web| url=http://www.angelfire.com/nj/sivritepe/0405/1.html | title=2004â2005 1.SÃ¼per Lig | work=ErdinÃ§ Sivritepe | accessdate=2007-06-17}} FenerbahÃ§e lost the title in the last week of the [[SÃ¼per Lig 2005â06|2005â06]] season to [[Galatasaray S.K. (football team)|Galatasaray]]. FenerbahÃ§e needed a win, but instead drew 1â1 with [[Denizlispor]] while Galatasaray won 3â0 over [[Kayserispor]]. Soon after, [[Christoph Daum]] stepped down as manager,{{cite web| url=http://www.fenerbahce.org/arama.asp?txtSearch=daum&sayfa=2# | title=TesekkÃ¼rlerimizle.. | work=Fenerbahce.org | date=16 June 2006 | accessdate=2007-05-29}} and was replaced by [[Zico]] on 4 July 2006.{{cite web| url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=373241&cc=5739 | title=Zico signs two-year Fenerbahce coaching deal | work=[[ESPN]]soccernet | date=4 July 2006 | accessdate=2007-05-29}} Zico began his reign by signing two new defenders, highly-touted Uruguayan international [[Diego Lugano]], and fellow [[Brazil]]ian [[Edu Dracena]].{{cite web| url=http://www.fenerbahce.org/detay.asp?ContentID=4433 | title=TÃ¼rkiye'nin en bÃ¼yÃ¼k takimina gidiyorum | work=Fenerbahce.org | date=17 August 2006 | accessdate=2007-05-29}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite web| url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/sport/archives/2006/08/28/2003325300 | title=Dracena to Fenerbahce |work=The Taipei Times | date=28 August 2006 | accessdate=2007-05-29}} Zico also signed two strikers, Serbian international [[Mateja KeÅ¾man]], and another Brazilian, [[Deivid de Souza|Deivid]].{{cite web| url=http://english.people.com.cn/200608/29/eng20060829_297735.html | title=Fenerbahce soccer club signs four-year contract with Mateja KeÅ¾man | work=[[People's Daily Online]] | date=29 August 2006 | accessdate=2007-05-29}} FenerbahÃ§e's [[SÃ¼per Lig 2006â07|2006â07]] domestic season started off with a 6â0 win over relegation candidates [[Kayseri Erciyesspor]].{{cite web| url=http://www.ligtv.com.tr/MacRaporu.aspx?m=14719 | title=MaÃ§ Raporu | work=LigTV.com.tr | date=5 August 2006 | accessdate=2007-05-29}} In the 32nd week of the [[SÃ¼per Lig 2006â07|SÃ¼per Lig]], FenerbahÃ§e drew Trabzonspor 2â2, while Besiktas J.K. lost to [[Bursaspor]] 0â3, putting the former out of contention for the title.{{cite web| url=http://www.ligtv.com.tr/MacRaporu.aspx?m=15218 | title=MaÃ§ Raporu | work=LigTV.com.tr | date=13 May 2007 | accessdate=2007-05-29}}{{cite web| url=http://www.ligtv.com.tr/MacRapoasdfasfsfasfru.aspx?m=15220 | title=MaÃ§ Raporu | work=LigTV.com.tr | date=13 May 2007 | accessdate=2007-05-29}} FenerbahÃ§e won their seventeenth Turkish SÃ¼per Lig title in [[SÃ¼per Lig 2006â07|2007]], the most in Turkey.{{cite web| url=http://www.uefa.com/footballeurope/news/kind=2/newsid=537891.html | title=FenerbahÃ§e handed Turkish crown | work=[[UEFA]].com | date=13 May 2007 | accessdate=2007-05-13}} FenerbahÃ§e started off their [[SÃ¼per Lig 2007â08|2007â08]] season by signing [[Brazil]]ian international [[Roberto Carlos (footballer)|Roberto Carlos]].{{cite web| url=http://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/clubfootball/news/newsid=533051.html | title=Fenerbahce sign Roberto Carlos | work=[[FIFA]].com | date=6 June 2007 | accessdate=2007-06-14 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071013200502/http://fifa.com/worldfootball/clubfootball/news/newsid=533051.html |archivedate = 13 October 2007}} The deal saw the defender come for free after his contract was not extended by [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]]. Young Turkish players like [[GÃ¶khan GÃ¶nÃ¼l]], [[Yasin Ãakmak]], [[Ilhan Parlak]], [[Ali Bilgin]], Turkish-English attacker [[Colin Kazim-Richards]], Turkish-Brazilian left back [[GÃ¶kÃ§ek Vederson]] joined FenerbahÃ§e in the beginning of the season and [[Chile national football team]] captain [[Claudio Maldonado]] joined the team in [[List of Turkish football transfers 2007â08|January '08 transfer window]]. On 11 January 2007, Fenerbahce S.K. was officially invited to [[G-14]].{{cite web| url=http://www.fenerbahce.org/eng/detay.asp?ContentID=652 | title=FenerbahÃ§e invited to G-14 | work=Fenerbahce.org | accessdate=2007-11-04}} G-14 is an association which consists of top clubs worldwide. FenerbahÃ§e S.K. is the only Turkish club that have been invited to this association. On March 2008, FenerbahÃ§e's record application was accepted by [[Guinness World Records|Guinness World Records Menagement Team]], which envisages FenerbahÃ§e to have the highest number of medal and trophy achievements on the planet with its 9 branches entirely, total of 1134 cups and medals.{{cite web| url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/spor/futbol/8487765.asp?gid=229&sz=3827 | title=FenerbahÃ§e en fazla kupa kazanan takim| work=hurriyet.com.tr | date=18 March 2008 | accessdate=2008-03-18}} In the [[1996â97 UEFA Champions League#Group C|UEFA Champions League 1996â97]] season FenerbahÃ§e completed the group stage with seven points{{cite web| url=http://www.uefa.com/ competitions/ucl/history/season=1996/round=76/group=17.html | title= UEFA Champions League 1996â97 Season}} and, amongst others, beat [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] 1â0 in [[Old Trafford]] undoing the record of the English giants being unbeaten for 40 years in their homeground. Under [[Zico]]âs command, [[FenerbahÃ§e]] qualified from the [[UEFA Champions League 2007â08#Group G|UEFA Champions League 2007â08 group stage]] for the first time in the club's history and went on to beat [[Sevilla FC]] to become a [[UEFA Champions League 2007â08#First knockout round|quarter-finalist in the 2007â08 season]]. So far, [[Zico]] is also the most successful manager of the team's history in the [[UEFA#Competitions|European arena]]. After successful scores both in local league of Turkey and international matches, [[Zico]] gained a new nickname from FenerbahÃ§e fans: ''Kral Arthur'' (meaning "King Arthur" in Turkish). Since 2000, FenerbahÃ§e S.K. improved the club's finances and facilities, bringing world stars to the club such as [[Haim Revivo]], [[Ariel Ortega]], [[Serhiy Rebrov]], [[Pierre van Hooijdonk]], [[Alex de Souza]], [[Stephen Appiah]], [[Nicolas Anelka]] and lately [[Mateja KeÅ¾man]], [[Roberto Carlos (footballer)|Roberto Carlos]], and [[Daniel GonzÃ¡lez GÃ¼iza|Dani GÃ¼iza]]. FenerbahÃ§e's [[2009â10 SÃ¼per Lig|2009â10]] season ended in shock as they lost the title on the last day. The FenerbahÃ§e players were told a draw would be enough towards the end of the match only to find out that other games went against their favour as [[Bursaspor]] beat [[BeÅiktaÅ J.K.|BeÅiktaÅ]] 2â1 to get the title. Despite the title loss, FenerbahÃ§e ended the season with the highest number of clean sheets (10), as well as the joint longest winning streak (8).{{cite news|url=http://www.whoscored.com/Regions/225/Tournaments/17/Seasons/1919|title=Turkish SÃ¼per Lig 2010 Streaks|publisher=WhoScored.com}} FenerbahÃ§e won a 18th [[SÃ¼per Lig]] title in the [[2010â11 SÃ¼per Lig|2010â11]] season. The team were nine points behind the leaders after 16 games, but went on an unbeaten run of 17 wins and one draw from the last 18 games of the season and won the title with 82 points. [[Trabzonspor]] also finished on 82 points but finished second due head-to-head goal average in favor of FenerbahÃ§e. [[Alexsandro de Souza|Alex]], became the top scorer of the season with 28 goals, the highest number of goals by a foreign player in history of [[Football in Turkey|Turkish football]].{{cite web|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-05-23/top-stories/29573442_1_league-title-fenerbahce-champions|title=Fenerbahce claim Turkish title for 18th time|date=23 May 2011|work=The Times of India |location=India|accessdate=25 May 2011}} Following the season's end club president [[Aziz YÄ±ldÄ±rÄ±m]] was remanded in custody over allegations of [[match-fixing]]. On 24 August 2011 FenerbahÃ§e was withdrawn from the Champions League by Turkey's Football Federation because of an ongoing match-fixing investigation.[http://www.uefa.com/uefa/footballfirst/matchorganisation/disciplinary/news/newsid=1666823.html FenerbahÃ§e replaced in UEFA Champions League][http://www.tff.org/default.aspx?pageID=285&ftxtID=13257 FenerbahÃ§e, Åampiyonlar Ligi'ne katÄ±lamayacak {{tr icon}}] ==Istanbul derbies== [[File:Galatasaray-FenerbahÃ§e match (1909).jpg|thumb|240px|The first KÄ±talar ArasÄ± Derbi on 17 January 1909 at PapazÄ±n ÃayÄ±rÄ±.]] {{Main|KÄ±talar ArasÄ± Derbi}} {{Main|BeÅiktaÅ vs FenerbahÃ§e}} "The big three" clubs of [[Istanbul]], [[BeÅiktaÅ J.K.]], FenerbahÃ§e S.K. and [[Galatasaray S.K.]] have a century-long history of rivalry. FenerbahÃ§e-Galatasaray rivalry is the primary Istanbul derby and the most important rivalry in Turkish football.{{Citation needed|date=January 2010}} The rivalry has led to violence among supporters on numerous occasions.{{cite news| title = Turkey to send anti-terror police to Leeds to protect Galatasaray | url = http://www.cbc.ca/sports/story/2000/04/17/galatasaray_leeds000417.html| publisher=CBC| date = 11 November 2000}} Other top level Ä°stanbul derbies include the teams; [[Ä°stanbul BÃ¼yÃ¼kÅehir Belediyespor (football team)|Ä°stanbul BB]] and [[KasÄ±mpaÅa S.K.|KasÄ±mpaÅa]] although these teams pose a minor rivalry as the history and the nation-wide attention to the derbies among the big three is unmatched. Torches, smoke, drums, flags and giant posters used to create visual grandeur and apply psychological pressure on visiting teams, which fans call "welcoming them to hell".{{cite news| title = Galatasaray find new home while 'Hell' rebuilt | url = http://www.abc.net.au/sport/content/s874472.htm| publisher=ABC Sport| date = 7 June 2003}} {{dead link|date=June 2011}} ==Club crest and colours== Since the club's foundation, FenerbahÃ§e has used the same badge, which has only undergone minor alterations. It was designed by [[Hikmet Topuzer]], nicknamed Topuz Hikmet, who played as left winger, in 1910 and had made as [[Lapel pin|lapel pins]] by Tevfik Haccar TaÅÃ§Ä± (then Tevfik Haccar) in [[London]]. The emblem consists of five colours. The white section which includes the writing ''FenerbahÃ§e Spor KulÃ¼bÃ¼ â 1907 â'' represents purity and open heartedness, the red section represents love and attachment to the club and symbolises the [[Flag of Turkey|Turkish flag]]. The yellow section symbolises other ones' envy and jealousy about FenerbahÃ§e, while the navy symbolises nobility. The [[oak]] leaf which rises from the navy and yellow section shows the force and the power of being a member of FenerbahÃ§e. The green colour of the leaf shows the success of FenerbahÃ§e is imperative.{{cite web| url=http://www.fenerbahce.org/eng/kurumsaldetay.asp?ContentID=16 | title=Emblem | work=Fenerbahce.org | accessdate=2007-04-15}} [[Hikmet Topuzer]] describes the story of the emblem as below: {{cquote|After the change of the clubâs colours from yellow and white to yellow and navy, it was an issue to create an emblem with our new colours. My friends left the design of this emblem to me. Firstly, I brought together the colours of our national flag, red and white. Then drew a heart shape over the red and gave it a yellow and navy colour, adding an acorn leaf that represents resistance, power and strength. I wrote the club name and foundation date on the white section. When drawing our emblem, I tried to give this meaning: Serving the club with dependence from heart. The design was favored by my friends and our new emblem was made through the guidance of Tevfik Haccar, who was in Germany at time. After the [[Turkish alphabet|new alphabet]] was approved, the design was protected, but the club name on the emblem was changed to FenerbahÃ§e Spor KulÃ¼bÃ¼ â 1907 â.}}

1923âpresent File:Old shirts.JPG|Old shirts
==Stadium== FenerbahÃ§e's football team play their home games at the [[ÅÃ¼krÃ¼ SaracoÄlu Stadium]] (simply known as Kadikoy) ,{{cite web| url=http://www.fenerbahce.org/stadyum/tr/index.asp | title=Wiew SaraÃ§oglu | work=[[FenerbahÃ§e]].org | accessdate=2007-09-02 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070825042631/http://www.fenerbahce.org/stadyum/tr/index.asp |archivedate = 25 August 2007}} in the [[KadÄ±kÃ¶y]] district of Istanbul, since 1908. Most recently renovated between 1999 and 2006, its capacity is 50,509.{{cite web| url=http://www.tff.org/Default.aspx?pageID=394&stadID=86 | title=Turkish Football Federation Information Pages for 2006â2007 Season | accessdate=2007-05-13}} Unusually for a Turkish football stadium there is no [[running track]] around the outside of the pitch. The club's museum has been situated in the stadium since 2005, after having been at a variety of locations.{{cite web| url=http://www.fenerbahce.org/fbmuze/ | title=FENERBAHÃE MÃZESI TARIHI | work=Fenerbahce.org | accessdate=2007-05-28}} === Other facilities === Other club facilities[http://www.fenerbahce.org/tesisler/index.asp Facilities page @ fenerbahce.org] include the social venue, the training complex, the club headquarters, the Dereagzi Metin Asik camp facilities, the youth academy football centre, the sports hall, the Fikirtepe facilities, the college, and the swimming pool.{{cite web| url=http://www.fenerbahce.org/kurumsaldetay.asp?ContentID=30 | title=Tesisler | work=[[FenerbahÃ§e]].org | accessdate=2007-06-17}} * ''[[Caferaga Sport Hall]]'', is a multi-purpose [[indoor arena]] located in [[KadÄ±kÃ¶y]] and opened in 1982. It is owned by the Municipality of KadÄ±kÃ¶y District and operated by the Directorate of Youth and Sport of [[Istanbul Province]].[http://www.istanbul-gsim.gov.tr/Default.asp?Section=Page&Act=Detail&ID=45 Directorate of Youth and Sport of Istanbul Province] {{tr icon}}Women's basketball team ([[FenerbahÃ§e Istanbul]]) and volleyball teams ([[FenerbahÃ§e Men's Volleyball]] and [[FenerbahÃ§e Women's Volleyball]]) play their league matches there. * ''[[FenerbahÃ§e Ãlker City]]'',[http://www.fenerbahce.org/tesisler/detay.asp?ContentID=23354 Ulker City @ fenerbahce.org] will be new hall with a capacity of 12,500. It is scheduled to be completed in summer of 2011.[http://fenerbahce.org/eng/detay.asp?ContentID=447 The Sport Hall will start to built in a year] The basketball teams ([[FenerbahÃ§e Ãlker]] and [[FenerbahÃ§e Istanbul]]), volleyball teams ([[FenerbahÃ§e Men's Volleyball]] and [[FenerbahÃ§e Women's Volleyball]]) will play their league matches there. * ''The [[Faruk Ilgaz]] Social Venue'', located next to the clubâs headquarters, is the new venue for the clubâs gatherings. It was initially opened 15 May 1969 but [[Aziz Yildirim]] rebuilt a modern complex and re-opened it on 21 January 2004.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} * ''Sancaktepe [[Can Bartu]] Training Facilities'', the construction for this top quality training complex began in 1997 during [[Ali Haydar Sen|Ali Sen]]âs presidency. The construction was completed in the year 2000. Serves the [[FenerbahÃ§e#Football|senior football team]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} * ''DereaÄzÄ± [[Lefter KÃ¼Ã§Ã¼kandonyadis]] Training Facilities'', serves [[FenerbahÃ§e S.K. A2|FenerbahÃ§e A2]] and is located at Dereagzi. Re-opened in 1989. Facilities also serve the [[FenerbahÃ§e Athletics|athletics branch]], the [[FenerbahÃ§e Boxing|boxing branch]], the [[FenerbahÃ§e Rowing|rowing branch]] and the [[FenerbahÃ§e Sailing|sailing branch]]. * ''Topuk YaylasÄ± Facilities'', serves [[FenerbahÃ§e SK]] all sport branches and located in [[DÃ¼zce|KaynaÅlÄ±, DÃ¼zce]]. The construction was started in 2010 and completed in 2011.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} * ''Youth Football Academy'', located next to the Metin Asik Camp Facilities. Built in 1999, serves the youth ranks of the football branch.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} * ''The Fikirtepe Facilities'', located on Yumurtaci Abdi Bey Road, [[KadÄ±kÃ¶y]]. Opened 1 July 1998, serves youth football development.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} * ''DereaÄzÄ± Samim GÃ¶reÃ§ Basketball Hall'', located on Munir Nurettin Selcuk Road Kiziltoprak. Refurbished 24 February 2001. First opened in 1982. Serves [[FenerbahÃ§e Ãlker]], [[FenerbahÃ§e Istanbul]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} * ''DereaÄzÄ± Muhtar Sencer Volleyball Hall'', located on Munir Nurettin Selcuk Road Kiziltoprak. Serves [[FenerbahÃ§e Men's Volleyball]] and [[FenerbahÃ§e Women's Volleyball]] teams.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} * ''Vefa KÃ¼Ã§Ã¼k Swimming Pool'', opened on 16 July 1999 and serves the swimming branch.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} * ''FenerbahÃ§e Olympic Swimming Pool'', is located in FenerbahÃ§e Island and opened in 2004. Serves the swimming branch.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} ==FenerbahÃ§e Museum== {{main|FenerbahÃ§e Museum}} FenerbahÃ§e Spor KulÃ¼bÃ¼ has won many trophies at the currently active branches and at some other branches which have been discontinued. {{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} During the Turkish War of Independence, FenerbahÃ§e played with many teams of the enemy and injected morale to the Turkish people by winning those games.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} FenerbahÃ§e Spor KulÃ¼bÃ¼âs football team has many records which are still not broken.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} Yet the success is not limited only with the football team.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} At the Olympics, the first gold medal was won by a FenerbahÃ§e athlete, [[Ruhi SarÄ±alp]], in a field other than wrestling. {{Citation needed|date=August 2011}}In athletics, the only club that wins the European Championship is FenerbahÃ§e. {{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} ==Club officials== ([[Free-To-Air]] on [[Turksat 2A|Turksat 3A]] located 42Â° East, 11957 V 27500 5/6), satellite network services and cable service.[http://www.fenerbahce.org/kurumsalkategori.asp?ContentCategoryID=36 Informations on Fenerbahce.org] ==FenerbahÃ§e Radio== {{Main|FB Radio}} ==Supporters== Since rebuilding the [[ÅÃ¼krÃ¼ SaracoÄlu Stadium]], FenerbahÃ§e's average attendances have been in the top in [[Turkey]].[http://www.samanyoluhaber.com/haber-42907.html FenerbahÃ§e on the top] FenerbahÃ§e have a number of supporters organisations, including [[GenÃ§ FenerbahÃ§eliler]] (GFB), [[Kill For You]] (KFY), Antu/Fenerlist, [[Group CK]] (CefakÃ¢r Kanaryalar), Vamos Bien, Anglofeb/FENatics, and SUADFEB. The supporters motto is ''Hep Destek Tam Destek'', abbreviated as HDTD (''Continuous Unwavering Support''{{lang-es|link=no|Te Apoyo Siempre, Te Apoyo En Todo}}). ==Branches== ====Football==== ''For A team's football'': {{main|FenerbahÃ§e S.K. (football team)}} ''For A2 team's football'': {{main|FenerbahÃ§e S.K. A2}} ''For football academy'': {{main|FenerbahÃ§e S.K. Academy}} ====Basketball==== FenerbahÃ§e's second biggest branch is the men basketball team. FenerbahÃ§e's men basketball department is sponsored by Ãlker. The women basketball branch is one of the most successful team of FenerbahÃ§e Sports Club.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} In last five years FenerbahÃ§e women basketball team won 13 of 15 cups that the team have competed.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} ''For men's basketball''[http://www.fenerbahce.org/kurumsal/kategori.asp?ContentCategoryID=38 Men's basketball squad] ''fenerbahce.org'' Retrieved on 23 September 2007 {{Main|FenerbahÃ§e Ãlker}} ''For women's basketball''[http://www.fenerbahce.org/kurumsal/kategori.asp?ContentCategoryID=39 Women's basketball squad] ''Fenerbahce.org'' Retrieved on 23 September 2007{{Main|FenerbahÃ§e Women's Basketball}} ====Volleyball==== FenerbahÃ§e's third biggest branch is the women volleyball team . FenerbahÃ§e's men volleyball department sponsored by Grundig. Women volleyball team known as '''Yellow Angels''', sponsored by Universal Hospitals. ''For men's volleyball''[http://www.fenerbahce.org/kurumsal/detay.asp?ContentID=78 Men's volleyball squad] ''Fenerbahce.org'' Retrieved on 9 October 2007 {{Main|FenerbahÃ§e Grundig}} ''For women's volleyball''[http://www.fenerbahce.org/kurumsal/detay.asp?ContentID=79 Women's volleyball squad] ''Fenerbahce.org'' Retrieved on 9 October 2007{{Main|FenerbahÃ§e Universal}} ====Athletics==== Athletics is an important branch of FenerbahÃ§e Spor Club. Team has important [[Sportsperson|athlete]]s who have Turkish records. [[Halil Akkas]] also member of [[FenerbahÃ§e Athletics]] branch and [[Esref Apak]] was. American [[Sprint (race)|sprinter]] [[Justin Gatlin]], Canadian sprinter [[Donovan Bailey]] and [[Jamaica]] born [[Slovenia]]n sprinter [[Merlene Ottey]] were also member of the team. ''For athletics''{{cite web| url=http://www.fenerbahce.org/kurumsal/kategori.asp?ContentCategoryID=2226 | title=Branches, Athletics | work=Fenerbahce.org | accessdate=2007-09-02}} {{Main|FenerbahÃ§e Athletics}} ====Boxing==== Boxing is an important branch of FenerbahÃ§e Spor Club. Team has important [[Boxing|boxers]] who have Turkish champions. [[AtagÃ¼n YalÃ§Ä±nkaya]], [[GÃ¼lsÃ¼m Tatar]] and [[SÃ¼meyra Kaya]] also members of [[FenerbahÃ§e Boxing]] branch.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} ''For boxing''{{cite web| url=http://www.fenerbahce.org/kurumsal/detay.asp?ContentID=6273 | title=Branches, Boxing | work=Fenerbahce.org | accessdate=2007-11-13}} {{Main|FenerbahÃ§e Boxing}} ====Rowing==== Rowing is an important branch of FenerbahÃ§e Spor Club.
